#Text=World 's defense chiefs meet in Singapore
#Text=Sunday , June 3 , 2007

#Text=The sixth Asia Security Conference , better known as the Shangri-La Dialogue , came to an end on Sunday in Singapore , highlighted by a visit by U.S. Defense Secretary Robert Gates and a senior Chinese defense official , Lt. Gen. Zhang Qisheng .

#Text=Named for its venue , the five-star Shangri-La Hotel Singapore , the annual meeting of top defense officials is organized by the International Institute for Strategic Studies , a London-based think tank .
#Text=The big issue at the Shangri-La gathering focused on China and its military buildup .
#Text=China has announced it will boost military spending by 17.8 percent in 2007 to 350.921 billion yuan ( about US$ 44.94 billion ) , the biggest increase in more than ten years .
#Text=But U.S. defense officials have said they believe actual spending is up to three times higher , and they have called on China to be more transparent .
#Text=" There 's no question that the Chinese are building significant capacity , " Gates said in Honolulu before he flew to Singapore .

column1: #Text=" Our concern is over their intent . "
#Text=China 's delegation was led by Zhang , the People 's Liberation Army deputy chief of the general staff .
#Text=In his address on Saturday , Zhang defended China 's reported defense-spending figures .

#Text=" In China , defense budgeting must follow a set of highly strict legal procedures , and the published Chinese defense budget is true and authentic , " he said , attributing the increase to inflation and logistical and welfare support of its troops . "

#Text=Given the multiple security threats , geo-political environment , the size of the territory , and the per-capita expense , the Chinese defense expenditure is small by all judgments ,  Zhang added .

#Text= In terms of our bilateral relationship , I would n't describe it as a breakthrough but as a next step in a process of military-to-military conversations which we will continue in the future . "

column1: #Text=For other countries in Asia , it 's China 's powerful economy that causes more concern , said Singaporean Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong in an opening speech on Friday .
#Text=" Most Asian countries assess the challenge from China to be more economic than military , " Lee said .

#Text=He added that China 's military build up is mainly a response to Taiwan , and he warned that if Taiwan seeks to further establish its independence , it could lead to " unintended and dangerous escalation of tensions between China and the U.S.

column3:
_	_	_	_

#Text=India , too , is flexing its military muscle , with Indian Defense Minister A. K. Antony giving a talk on Saturday ,  China and India : Building International Stability . "

column1: #Text=" India is ready to play its role in the shaping of this new approach to collective security , " Antony said .

#Text=" Only a pluralistic security order working through a network of cooperative structures can have the legitimacy as well as the wherewithal to deal with the security challenges of the 21st century . "

column1: #Text=Other delegations included Australia , Canada , France , Germany , Japan , South Korea and the United Kingdom .
#Text=Concern about Iran 's nuclear program came up in comments by Gates on Saturday , saying stronger penalties are needed against Iran " not next year or the year after , but right now . "
#Text=Gates did not rule out military action to stop Iran 's nuclear research , even if it was n't the most attractive option . "

column3:
_	_	_	_

#Text=Probably everybody in this room wants there to be a diplomatic solution to this problem ,  he said .

#Text= Having to take care of this problem militarily is in no one 's interest . "

column1: #Text=On a tour of the Asia-Pacific region , Gates also worked to assure his counterparts in other countries that the United States ' involvement in Iraq would not undermine its role in Asia .
#Text=" While we are fighting in Iraq and Afghanistan and the global war on terror , we have no intention of neglecting Asia , " Gates said on Friday in Honolulu .

#Text=In particular , Gates said the U.S. is keen to develop better relations with Central Asian states , and he called on other countries in the region to reach out and help Afghanistan and its neighbors , such as Kazakhstan , Turkmenistan , Uzbekistan , Kyrgyzstan and Tajikistan .
#Text="

#Text= We are not satisfied with the current state but we are pleased with the progress we 've made , " he said , noting that their security cooperation has improved and there have been no recent major incidences of piracy in the Strait .

column1: #Text=The issue of Myanmar and its military government came up during Prime Minister Lee 's talk on Friday , with Lee saying the Association of Southeast Asian Nations , or ASEAN , " ought not to be hostage with the problems with Myanmar . "
#Text=ASEAN has come under pressure for its admission of Myanmar , which is ruled by a junta that has refused to cede to a democratically elected government .
#Text=But ASEAN has a policy of non-engagement in internal conflicts of its members .
#Text=" We will leave Myanmar to work itself out , " Lee said .
